metadata.titleEn: Dataset on the freeze-thaw process in Antarctic and Arctic ice sheets (1978-2015)
metadata.description: This dataset is the spatial distribution map of the marshes in the source area of the Yellow River near the Zaling Lake-Eling Lake, covering an area of about 21,000 square kilometers. The data set is classified by the Landsat 8 image through an expert decision tree and corrected by manual visual interpretation. The spatial resolution of the image is 30m, using the WGS 1984 UTM projected coordinate system, and the data format is grid format. The image is divided into five types of land, the land type 1 is “water body”, the land type 2 is “high-cover vegetation”, the land type 3 is “naked land”, and the land type 4 is “low-cover vegetation”, and the land type 5 is For "marsh", low-coverage vegetation and high-coverage vegetation are distinguished by vegetation coverage. The threshold is 0.1 to 0.4 for low-cover vegetation and 0.4 to 1 for high-cover vegetation.
metadata.instructions: The dataset files are uniformly packaged in the “result” folder, and the “resultgrid” grid format file can be opened using ArcGis software to view the classification results of the Yellow River source marsh. You can use the ArcGis Import Symbology feature to import a preset layer by opening the "resultgrid.lyr" layer file.

background: Monitoring ice-sheet snowmelt is fundamental to understanding global climate change. Different ice-sheet snowmelt detection methods are based on a variety of thresholding schemes using different melt signals for dry and wet snow; these complicate the regular operation of an ice-sheet snowmelt monitoring.
research objective: We propose an automated melt signal detection method developed using melt signals derived from the cross-gradient polarization ratio snowmelt detection.
methods: We processed the data spanning from 25 October 1978 to 30 June 2010 in Antarctica, and from 1 July 1988 to 30 June 1995 in Greenland. We employed the 18-GHz horizontal polarization channel and 37-GHz vertically polarized channel from the SMMR data, and the 19-GHz horizontal channel and 37-GHz vertically polarized channel from the SSM/I and SSMIS data. Using the regression coefficients presented by Liu et al. (2005), Jezek et al. (1991) and Abdalati et al. (1995), the SMMR, SSM/I F11 and SSM/I F13 data are converted into SSM/I F8 equivalent values for the Antarctic and Greenland ice sheets. In addition, to validate the result, the temperature measurements of automatic weather stations (AWSs) in Antarctica and Greenland were also collected. We use in situ data to validate the daily snowmelt detection results of each method. For processing the AWS data, we chose the daily mean air temperature data from the summer months (November /C1 March) in Antarctica. Once the corresponding daily detection results have been obtained by using the snowmelt detection method, the following defined quantities (Celik 2010) are computed for comparing the daily detection results against the corresponding daily mean air temperature data.
dataset: The test sites we selected in this study are the Antarctic continent and Greenland. The satellite passive microwave data used for this analysis are from the Scanning Multi-channel Microwave Radiometer (SMMR) data collected by the US National Aeronautical and Space Administration’s Nimbus-7 satellite, the Special Sensor Microwave/Imager (SSM/I) data collected by the DMSP-F8, -F11 and -F13 satellites and the Special Sensor Microwave Imager Sounder (SSMIS) data collected by the DMSP-F17 satellite. We processed the data spanning from 25 October 1978 to 30 June 2010 in Antarctica, and from 1 July 1988 to 30 June 1995 in Greenland. In addition, to validate the result, the temperature measurements of automatic weather stations (AWSs) in Antarctica and Greenland were also collected.
findings: Using temperature data to validate the snowmelt detection results of the modified XPGR detection method and the modified wavelet transformation-based method shows that they have relatively high precision.

Verification.Question: Is the precision of ice-sheet snowmelt detection methods validated using temperature measurements from automatic weather stations?
Does the data collection method for snowmelt detection involve using different frequency channels from satellite-based passive microwave sensors?

Disjunctive.Question: Which remote sensing technique is more applicable for detecting ice-sheet snowmelt, microwave radiometer data or microwave scatterometer data?

Concept Completion.Question: What data sources are used to monitor ice-sheet snowmelt in the Antarctic and Greenland regions?
Concept Completion.Answer: Scanning Multi-channel Microwave Radiometer (SMMR), Special Sensor Microwave/Imager (SSM/I), Special Sensor Microwave Imager Sounder (SSMIS)

Concept Completion.Question: What methodological challenges are associated with detecting ice-sheet snowmelt using microwave radiometer data?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for monitoring ice-sheet snowmelt that effectively separates dry and wet snow signals?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method for monitoring ice-sheet snowmelt is using the cross-gradient polarization ratio to derive melt signals. This method employs microwave radiometer data, utilizing different frequency channels to distinguish between dry and wet snow conditions.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that spans multiple decades and is used to monitor changes in the ice-sheet snowmelt of Antarctica and Greenland?
Example.Answer: A dataset example is the long-term microwave radiometer data that covers Antarctica from 1978 to 2010 and Greenland from 1988 to 1995. This dataset includes data from the SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMIS sensors, which have been cross-corrected for consistency across different sensors.

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the microwave scatterometer data used in the ice-sheet melt detection datasets?

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of different satellite microwave sensors enhance the precision of detecting ice-sheet snowmelt patterns over extended time periods?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of different satellite microwave sensors, such as the SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMIS, provides a means to cross-validate and correct brightness temperature data across varying time frames and spatial resolutions. This approach ensures temporal consistency and improves the accuracy of ice-sheet snowmelt detection by utilizing regression coefficients to convert data into equivalent values. Additionally, high temporal resolution from scatterometer data aids in distinguishing dry and wet snow, contributing to more precise detection of melt signals.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological considerations are necessary when using wavelet transformation and variance analysis in detecting ice-sheet snowmelt, and how do these methods address noise in the data?
Interpretation.Answer: Wavelet transformation allows for the multi-scale decomposition of long-term brightness temperature data, enabling detailed analysis of edge information that indicates snowmelt. Variance analysis helps separate melt-induced edge information from noise. The combination of these methods effectively distinguishes true melt signals from noise by identifying optimal edge thresholds for dry and wet snow classification. Furthermore, spatial error correction principles are applied to detect and rectify errors caused by noise, enhancing the reliability of the results.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of detecting ice-sheet snowmelt using microwave radiometer and scatterometer data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity arises from the use of different thresholding schemes for dry and wet snow, which require careful analysis of melt signals, as well as the need to account for the brightness temperature changes over time and space. The process involves techniques like wavelet transformation and variance analysis to separate noise and identify melt areas accurately.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on data accuracy when utilizing microwave radiometer data over a long time series for detecting ice sheet snowmelt?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing microwave radiometer data over a long time series for detecting ice sheet snowmelt, as described in the field, results in high precision snowmelt detection due to consistent processing methods and validation through temperature measurements from automatic weather stations.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of both microwave radiometer and scatterometer data influence the detection of melt and refreeze processes in polar ice sheets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of microwave radiometer and scatterometer data allows for improved detection of melt and refreeze processes by leveraging the high spatial resolution of scatterometer data and the temporal consistency of radiometer data, resulting in more accurate threshold determination and snow classification.

Causal Consequence.Question: What effects could the application of an automated melt signal detection method have on the operational efficiency of ice-sheet monitoring?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The application of an automated melt signal detection method enhances operational efficiency by simplifying the monitoring process, reducing manual intervention, and providing a reliable means of distinguishing between dry and wet snow, which is crucial for accurate ice-sheet snowmelt detection.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of employing microwave radiometers and scatterometers in the data collection method for monitoring ice-sheet snowmelt?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose is to utilize the strengths of microwave radiometers and scatterometers in capturing long-term brightness temperature data and high-resolution temporal data, respectively, to effectively detect snowmelt on polar ice sheets. These instruments allow for the application of advanced algorithms to analyze the temporal changes and spatial characteristics of the ice sheets, leading to accurate detection of melt and freeze processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop an automated melt signal detection method using cross-gradient polarization ratio in ice-sheet snowmelt studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing an automated melt signal detection method is important to streamline and standardize the monitoring process of ice-sheet snowmelt, minimizing complications arising from various thresholding schemes. This method aims to improve the accuracy and reliability of detecting melt signals by addressing the challenges of differentiating between dry and wet snow, thus enhancing our understanding of ice-sheet dynamics in the context of global climate change.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be employed to ensure consistency in brightness temperature data across different microwave radiometers for ice-sheet melt detection?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure consistency in brightness temperature data across different microwave radiometers, cross-sensor calibration is applied. This involves using regression coefficients from previous studies to convert data from sensors like SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMIS into equivalent values. Additionally, cross-correction is performed before extracting freeze-thaw information to maintain temporal consistency.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are taken to validate snowmelt detection results using in situ temperature data from automatic weather stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Validation involves collecting temperature data from automatic weather stations (AWSs) in Antarctica and Greenland. The daily mean air temperature from summer months is used to compare against snowmelt detection results. By computing defined quantities such as the mean and variance, the accuracy of the detection method is assessed, ensuring reliable snowmelt monitoring.

Enablement.Question: What remote sensing technologies enable the detection of ice-sheet snowmelt over extensive time periods?
Enablement.Answer: The use of microwave radiometers and scatterometers, specifically sensors like SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMIS, enable the detection of ice-sheet snowmelt by providing long-term passive microwave brightness temperature data. These technologies allow for the monitoring of snowmelt phenomena over extensive periods, from 1978 to 2015, with varying spatial resolutions.

Enablement.Question: What factors facilitate the validation of snowmelt detection results derived from satellite data?
Enablement.Answer: Validation of snowmelt detection results is facilitated by comparing satellite data with in situ temperature measurements from automatic weather stations in Antarctica and Greenland. This comparison ensures that the snowmelt detection methods align with actual temperature variations, thereby confirming their accuracy and reliability.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect challenges in validating snowmelt detection results using temperature measurements from automatic weather stations?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might face challenges in validating snowmelt detection results with automatic weather station temperature data because the spatial resolution of satellite data is much coarser than point measurements from weather stations. This mismatch can lead to discrepancies when comparing remote sensing-based snowmelt detection results with localized temperature readings.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how can data collection methods be improved to enhance the precision of ice sheet melt detection using spaceborne microwave sensors?
Judgmental.Answer: To enhance precision, data collection methods could potentially incorporate higher spatial resolution sensors and more advanced algorithms that consider both spatial and temporal variations in snow characteristics, as well as improved noise correction techniques to refine melt detection thresholds.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out why different snowmelt detection methods would complicate the regular monitoring of ice-sheet snowmelt.
Assertion.Answer: Different snowmelt detection methods use various thresholding schemes for distinguishing melt signals in dry and wet snow, which can introduce complexities in standardizing and automating ice-sheet snowmelt monitoring processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the methods used to ensure consistency in brightness temperature data across different sensors in long-term ice-sheet monitoring datasets.
Request/Directive.Answer: To ensure consistency in brightness temperature data across different sensors, a cross-correction of brightness temperatures is performed before melt detection. This involves using regression coefficients to convert SMMR, SSM/I F11, and SSM/I F13 data into SSM/I F8 equivalent values for the Antarctic and Greenland ice sheets. This step is crucial for maintaining temporal consistency in the datasets used for monitoring the ice-sheet snowmelt.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential challenges in utilizing microwave radiometer and scatterometer data for polar ice-sheet melt detection.
Request/Directive.Answer: Some potential challenges in utilizing microwave radiometer and scatterometer data include dealing with the temporal and spatial variability of snow properties, ensuring data consistency across different sensors, and removing noise-induced errors. Techniques such as wavelet transformation and variance analysis are used to manage these challenges by extracting and analyzing edge information and distinguishing melt processes. Additionally, spatial neighborhood error correction operators help address errors caused by noise.
